=== BIOS ===
The first action you'll want to take is to enter into your <nowiki>[[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BIOS | BIOS]]</nowiki>. If you've never done this before, it can be achieved by pushing '''F2''' Key or '''DEL''' Key or '''F10''' Key while your computer is turning on. Lenovo has a special button to enter the bios that looks like an arrow with a curve in it.  This may take a few tries, but one of the buttons will work.

Once you're in the BIOS, poke around a bit using the arrow keys to navigate, and the enter key to "click".  Spend a little time looking around and search for things you don't understand.

The real thing you're looking for is the '''Boot Order'''. Before the install, you will need to change this so that your '''CD drive''' or '''USB drive''' is the first device to boot from.

=== Creating Installation Media ===
There are several ways to install Ubuntu GNOME, and each has its advantages. USB is faster than DVD. Either way should work provided your system supports booting from a USB drive if you follow these directions exactly. If either of these methods doesn't work, <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuGNOME/ContactUs#Ask_for_Help_.26_Support | Please Contact Us!]]</nowiki>.

You need to create or borrow an Ubuntu GNOME DVD or USB-stick. Once you have an Ubuntu DVD or USB it should work as an installer and as a <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/LiveCD | LiveDVD]]</nowiki> or <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Installation/FromUSBStick | LiveUSB]]</nowiki>.

==== Creating a LiveDVD ====
Prerequisites for installation with a LiveDVD are:
* A blank DVD-R or DVD-RW '''Note: you cannot use a CD, because they are not big enough.'''
* A computer that supports booting from a DVD.  Most do, unless they don't have a DVD drive.

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <( |2 style="background-color: #ffeeaa; color: #000000; padding: 5px 20px; border-radius: 10px; width: 90%; border: none;">HOWTO Create a LiveCD/LiveDVD<<BR>>Please Read: <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BurningIsoHowto | Burning ISO]]</nowiki>
|}
<<BR>>
Once you have burned the disc and changed your boot order (as described in <nowiki>[[#BIOS | BIOS]]</nowiki>), just put the disc in your drive, and reboot.  Follow the guide of your choice from <nowiki>[[#Final_Install | Final Install]]</nowiki> to complete the installation.

==== To create a LiveUsb ====
Prerequisites for installation with a LiveUSB are:
* A computer that supports booting from a USB (Check your bios).
* A USB drive of 2GB or more.
* Your preferred <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuGNOME/GetUbuntuGNOME | Download]]</nowiki> of Ubuntu GNOME.

Once you have created the LiveUSB and changed your boot order (as described in <nowiki>[[#BIOS | BIOS]]</nowiki>), just put the disc in your drive, and reboot. Follow the guide of your choice from <nowiki>[[#Final_Install | Final Install]]</nowiki> to complete the installation.

For more information, please have a read at: <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Installation/FromUSBStick | Installing from USB]]</nowiki>.

=== Final Install ===
==== Cross-grading from Ubuntu To Ubuntu GNOME ====
First, you install the Ubuntu GNOME desktop, and enable GDM.
<pre>
sudo apt-get install ubuntu-gnome-desktop^
</pre>
** dpkg will prompt asking which display manager you want to use, select 'gdm'

Optionally, you can remove unneeded packages from Ubuntu.

<pre>
sudo apt-get purge ubuntu-default-settings
</pre>
<pre>
sudo apt-get purge ubuntu-desktop
</pre>
<pre>
sudo apt-get autoremove
</pre>
==== Basic or Auto Installation ====
This could be the easiest and shortest installation type. However, you should note that this will wipe any other system installed on the machine you are installing Ubuntu GNOME on.

==== Manual Installation ====
This is the most customizable type of installation. It gives you more control over the installation process but a basic knowledge of <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/12.04/installation-guide/i386/partitioning.html | Ubuntu Partitioning]]</nowiki> is required - also see <nowiki>[[http://askubuntu.com/questions/343268/how-to-use-manual-partitioning-during-installation | HOWTO use Manual Partitioning during Installation]]</nowiki>. It is not a rocket science, yet you need to proceed with caution. In another word, you need to know what you're doing. There are lots of information on the internet (videos, HOWTOs, articles, etc).

=== Accessibility Options ===
To install with accessibility options enabled, press '''F5''' after you select your language and pick the options that you require.  To use the speech installer, press '''CTRL + S''' after the disc has loaded.  This will also enable GNOME screen reader on the installed system.  Once your system is installed, the accessibility features can be re-enabled via the '''System Settings''', in case you disable them by mistake.

For more information, see <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuGNOME/Accessibility | Accessibility]]</nowiki>
